comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Harvey Washington Wiley (October 30, 1844 - June 30, 1930) was a noted chemist best known for his leadership in the passage of the landmark Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 and his subsequent work at the Good Housekeeping Institute laboratories. He was the first commissioner of the US Food and Drug Administration. ... In 1912, Wiley resigned and took over the laboratories of Good Housekeeping magazine, where he continued his work on behalf of the consuming public. His disapprobation of "drugged" products included as the caffeine in cola drinks, against which he warned as vehemently as he would have against the cocaine they had once contained. In a famous action brought against the Coca-Cola company in 1911, he contended that it was illegal to use the name Coca-Cola when there was no actual cocaine in the drink, and also that it was illegal for it to contain caffeine as an additive. Perversely, this was as much as to say that the product ought to have contained cocaine and not caffeine. Still, the case was a landmark in developing standards for truth in labelling. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_W._Wiley

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Thanks for Wiley's fuller name.  We'll add it to the description next time we update the recors.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Hazen J. Titus became Northern Pacific's superintendent of dining cars in 1908. He introduced " The Great Big Baked Potato " and other regional items, see www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/hazen-titus-fruit-cake-tin... and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baked_potato In 1913, he suppressed the fingerbowls in the dining cars because they were unsanitary (The Daily Missoulian., November 08, 1913, Morning, Page 5, column 1)

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: A. D. Charlton was assistant general passenger agent of the Northern Pacific Railways, see e.g. The ranch., August 01, 1911, Page 14 (advertisement) Pullman herald., March 16, 1917, Image 1, "OPENING OF NEW N. P. DEPOT ATTRACTS TREMENDOUS CROWD", where he is mentioned together with H.J. Titus East Oregonian, July 27, 1908, EVENING EDITION, Page 8, column 5, "PREDICTS BIG WHEAT CROP"

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: George Ainslie: According to www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=6918704, this was George Ainslie (1868 - 1931), Mayor of Richmond, Virginia from 1912 to 1924 (at least there is this photo of him). But there are other photos of him in the newspapers, p.e. in The times dispatch., August 23, 1912, Image 1 or The times dispatch., April 29, 1914, Image 1 and I think it's another person. His wikipedia entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Ainslie_%28Virginia_politici... Another George Ainslie was Congressional delegate from Idaho Territory, which would make sense, if the photo was in connection with the Idaho baked potato, but this man would be to old (he died in 1913, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Ainslie_%28delegate%29). The man on the photo could be a son of him, but that's only a guess.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: B-59: Thanks for the additional name research. We will add more information to the record.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This photo may have something to do with Dr. Wiley's endorsement, on a 1913 train menu, of the purity of the food served on Northern Pacific Railroad. digitum.washingtonhistory.org/cdm/singleitem/collection/e... LOC also has an item, not online, that is a group of 6 photos described as "Tributes paid Dr. Wiley by the Northern Pacific Railroad and others, ca. 1910" www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2005690454/ This 1915 NPRR ad, has a quote by Wiley under a photos of Hazen J. Titus' Great Big Baked Potato. books.google.com/books?id=MZcwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA40&lp... Likewise in this 1913 newpaper ad: oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-03-25/ed-1/se...
